results.title: Jane Conquest magic lantern slides
results.brief_description:
Creator, York & Son, England. Burning ship.
Narrative for slide “The cottage wall dissolved to reveal a ship in flames not far from the wintry shore. Jane was sole witness of this dreadful sight, the only villager astir to hear the despairing shouts of the victims.”
results.description:

results.title: Jane Conquest magic lantern slides
results.brief_description:
Creator, York & Son, England. Woman standing, holding baby.
Narrative for slide “The window was crimsoned with the flickering reflection of a fire, and the next slide, flashed on with lightning speed, showed Jane starting up to the casement.”
results.description:

results.title: Jane Conquest magic lantern slides
results.brief_description:
Creator, York & Son, England. Woman sitting, holding baby.
Narrative for slide: “At these words the curtain went up to disclose Jane Conquest, a strong featured, sturdy young woman in a red shawl, seated with her sick child on her lap by a cheerless grate in a cottage interior with a Gothic stone hearth and a latticed window. The tearing, whistling crescendo and diminuendo of a great storm almost drowned the voice of the narrator and a distant, bloodcurdling cry.”
results.description:

results.title: Spotlights: David Gulpilil
results.brief_description: A Yolŋu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. He reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971) and Storm Boy (1976).

constellations_primary.name: David Gulpilil
constellations_primary.description: David Gulpilil is a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Gulpilil was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

results.description: David Gulpilil is a Yolngu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. As an actor, he reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with principal roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971), Storm Boy (1976) and The Last Wave (1977). He also initiated and narrated the film Ten Canoes (2006).
description_for_label: David Gulpilil is a Yolngu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. As an actor, he reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with principal roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971), Storm Boy (1976) and The Last Wave (1977). He also initiated and narrated the film Ten Canoes (2006).

images.alt_text: An image of legendary Indigenous actor David Gulpilil, with a white beard and hair tied back in a pony tail, wearing a blue shirt and dark brown jacket with the bush obscured in the background

results.title: House in Summer slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a English style house and gardens. Several pencil marking on the wood. On the underside, ‘57’ has been written in a thick white ink.

results.title: Knight and Princess slipping slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with dark wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a a princess pushes a knight from her window or cuts his climbing rope, resulting in his fall Set against a black background.

results.title: Boy and Girl slipping slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with dark wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a a figure changes from girl features to boy features. Set against a black background. Brown tape adhered to moving slide.

results.title: Flower bloom three panel slipping slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a flower bud blooming. Two adjustable sliding pieces of glass - slide left and right to show the flower blooming. Set against a black background. Made by W.F. Archer, Liverpool, 43 Lord St and 63 South Castle St. ‘49’ and ‘R’ written in pencil on wooden frame.
results.description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a flower bud blooming. results.title: Man and Donkey lever slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a portrait of a man wearing a hat in a circular slide. An adjustable handle allows the viewer to move a beard.

results.title: Toy lantern slides
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description: There are three parts to the Reptiles slides, each slide has 4 images. These small slides have red sealing tape around the edges. These slides form part of The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit with removable chimney and internal wooden block. The lantern is housed in original box with metal handle, and internal red and blue graphic for: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit. 20 glass slides in custom box, length of textile to keep box shut, 2 small empty boxes which act to store slides in a snug manner.
